Stephen Wright, B.Sc (Econ.), M.Litt, has been the Executive Director of the European Centre for Health Assets and Architecture (ECHAA) since the organisation’s founding in 2009.  ECHAA is a research centre and strategic advisory group focusing on the interface between the facilities of the healthcare sector and the delivery of services.  Formerly, he was Associate Director at the European Investment Bank where he worked in a variety of economic sectors (energy, industry, transport and waste management).  In 1997, he took responsibility to develop the then new operational areas of education and health (“human capital”).  Initially a trial lending initiative limited in time and geography, the human capital sectors became a mainstream and major lending programme.  Mr Wright was a founder Steering Committee member of the European Observatory on Health Systems and Policies, during 1997-2007, and latterly was involved in writing and editing two Observatory books – Investing in hospitals of the future and Capital investment for health.  He holds an Honorary Research Fellowship at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.

Current positions:

Jeremy was appointed Leadership Chair in eHealth Research at the University of Leeds (UK) in 2012 to set up a new programme of research and training in digital healthcare. He is also Clinical Adviser on new information & communication technologies to the Royal College of Physicians in London. His research aims to uncover scientific principles to guide the design of clinical information and eHealth systems, so focuses on evaluation of tools that change the behaviour of clinicians (eg. decision support systems), patients (eg. self-care apps, telehealth) and the public (eg. apps or SMS msgs for promoting healthy lifestyle). He is also concerned about the social impact of these technologies and contributes to eHealth, behaviour change and innovation policy debates.

 

Brief education background:

Jeremy trained in medicine in Oxford and London Universities and as a hospital physician in Oxford, London & Glasgow, obtaining his MRCP in 1983. He then discovered the emerging medical informatics discipline and carried out doctoral training at London University (Westminster Medical School, National Heart & Lung Institute) and an MRC-funded post doc at Stanford.

 

Main achievements:

Jeremy set up the Institute for Digital Healthcare in Warwick University in 2010, the Dundee Health Informatics & eHealth Research Centre 2005-10 and the NICE R&D programme 2003-5. He was a member of the WHO mHealth Technical Advisory Group 2010-12. He is visiting professor in Oxford, Amsterdam and Oporto universities and served as Academic Adviser on Knowledge Management to the National Health Service 2002-5. He wrote the agenda for and minuted the McMaster meeting in June 1992 which, with Brian Haynes & Iain Chalmers, established the global Cochrane Collaboration; he also set up Cochrane’s Effective Practice & Organisation of Care review group in 1994. He has written three textbooks on eHealth, five series of tutorial article for major medical journals and 200 articles in all. He was the UK’s first elected Fellow of the American college of Medical Informatics in 1997, was ranked third worldwide in his discipline in 2009 and has given 40 invited overseas lectures in the last decade, including the Spinoza lecture in Amsterdam. In his spare time he makes jewellery and commemorative objects in titanium and precious metals.

 

(last updated 27.09.2015)

Alexandra Wyke, Doctor, is founder of the UK-based consultancy, PatientView. Between 1996 and April 2000, Alex was responsible for creating and running a successful international healthcare publishing unit at the Economist Intelligence Unit. Between 1983 and 1996, Alex was the business and science correspondent for The Economist. Aside from her work in The Economist, her other publications include: articles in the Harvard Business Review, the Daily Telegraph, The Economist's The World in 1995, 1996, etc; a chapter in Going Digital, and a business report on motivating managers, published by The Economist Group. In 1997, her book, 21st-Century Miracle Medicine, was published by Plenum (see Amazon.com). Alex has a PhD in biochemistry. She is married with one son.

Sally Wyke, Prof, Dr, BSc PhD, FRCGP (hon)

Sally is Interdisciplinary Professor of Health and Wellbeing at the University of Glasgow.  She studied Human Sciences at University College London, and did her PhD in Healthcare Research at the University of Newcastle upon Tyne.  She is a social scientist who applies social scientific theory and methods to complex interventions to improve health and well-being.  She also has expertise in developing pragmatic approaches to robust evaluation of complex interventions using comparative designs and mixed methods and applies her skills to support health in community and primary care settings.  She was co-PI (with Kate Hunt) on “Football Fans in Training” (FFIT) a hugely successful lifestyle programme for men delivered through Scottish top flight football clubs.  She is PI on EuroFIT, an FP7 award, that extends the ideas of FFIT to football clubs in Europe.

Miroslaw J. Wysocki M.D., Ph D., Polish, Medical Doctor – specialisation degrees in Public Health, Epidemiology, Internal Medicine; Director of the National Institute of Public Health (NIH), Warsaw, Poland; 1988-2000 Regional Advisor on Health Situation and Trends Assessment, WHO/South – East Asia Office, New Delhi, India; 2000 – 2008 President of the Sanitary – Epidemiological Council to the  Minister of Health; 2010 – 2011 National Consultant in Public Health. Since 2010 member of RC WHO/EURO Standing Committee. During Polish EU Presidency (2011) chaired Senior Level Public Health Working Group of EC. Research and publications (130) mainly in the area of public health and NCD’ s epidemiology.

Chief coordinator of international epidemiological studies of chronic diseases  (COPDs, diabetes, rheumatic diseases). Participant and coordinator of congresses and working groups organized by WHO, International Epidemiological Association (IEA), EUPHA, ASPHER and National Institutes of Health (USA). Many times represented Poland at WHO World Health Assemblies and   WHO Regional Committees.

Prof. Gonghuan Yang, Former deputy Director General of China CDC, worked in the Institute of Basic Medical Science at Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences now. She is the famous epidemiologist on public health, especially Chronic disease control and tobacco control in China, Her most important distribution is to set up the National Disease Surveillance Point System covered 10 million population. Another research interest focuses tobacco control. Prof. Yang did a depth research on health risk of tobacco use, prevalence of tobacco use, difference between FCTC and related domestic Law and regulations, control pattern, evaluating strategy and indicators of intervention on tobacco control. And she provided the research evidences on water pollution and cancer in Hui river areas of China. After 2000, she became a leader of tobacco control in China to push tobacco control.
V Yanin; Minister of Public Health Krasnoyarsk Region, Russian Federation

Dr Wendy Yared is Director of the Association of European Cancer Leagues (ECL), a pan-European alliance of national and regional cancer leagues created in 1980. ECL facilitates the collaboration among cancer leagues throughout Europe and influence EU and pan-European policies by working closely with the European Commission and European Parliament. Dr Yared works with the Board and member leagues toward ECL’s vision for a Europe free of cancers.

At the EU level, she is on the Commission’s Expert Group on Cancer Control, is an Associated Partner of the current European Commission Joint Action in Cancer Control (Cancon 2014-2017) for dissemination.  She was previously the leader for the Health Promotion and Prevention work package within the previous Joint Action Partnership for Action Against Cancer 2011-2014, led ECL to relaunch the European Week Against Cancer end of May, and to mobilise national organisations and local schools to participate in grass roots awareness-raising activities such as flash mobs and youth competitions for health promotion and cancer prevention and communicating the European Code Against Cancer. Dr Yared is active in the Commission’s Platform on Diet, Physical Activity and Health, as well as a founding member of the EU Alcohol and Health Forum.

Dr Yared has more than 25 years’ experience in public health. She was previously with the World Health Organization, worked with the European Parliament and the United States Public Health Service, and is currently an advisor on international health systems and policy issues.

 

(last updated 10.09.2015)

Sea-Wain Yau; CEO John Tung Foundation; Yau received his JD degree from University of Iowa College of Law and licensed to practice law in California, U.S.A.  In addition to his post in John Tung Foundation, Yau is also a full-time law professor at Soochow University and the Secretary-General for the Chinese (Taipei) Society of International Law.  Since joining the academia, he has taught Public International Law, International Trade Law, U.S. Constitution, Law of Negotiable Instrument, Anglo-American Law on Torts and Anglo-American Law on Contract.  The author of numerous articles, Professor Yau's scholarship reflects his various academic interests, including transnational anti-corruption regulations, public interest test in anti-dumping imposition, legitimacy of war under international law, and transnational tobacco litigations.

Abdul Satar Yoosuf; Dr, is presently Assistant Regional Director at the World Health Organization’s South-East Asia Regional Office. Previous to that, he had been Director of the Department of Sustainable Development and Healthy Environments in the South East Asia Regional Office of WHO. Prior to joining WHO, Dr Sattar Yoosuf occupied key positions in the Maldives health system from 1975 to 1994 including that of Director General of Health Services, and key deputy Ministerial posts in the Ministry of Health and in the Ministry of Planning.  During his close to two decades of service to the Maldives government, he assisted with the design of the Maldives health system along the lines of PHC in 1978, devised public health system measures on sanitation and food hygiene in the country, and put in significant effort on eradicating Malaria from the country which materialized in 1986. Another vital contribution of his was the initiation of a mobile health team strategy to the outlying dispersed islands of the country. He was also his country’s member on WHO Executive Board for the three year period 1991-1993. Dr Sattar Yoosuf holds a doctorate in Health Policy and Management from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, US.

Ane Fullaondo obtained the MD in Biology at the Automous University of Madrid (2005) and Phd in Genetics and Molecular Biology by the University of the Basque Country (2009). She studied a Master in research methods and evaluation of health services, and health economics of the National Distance Education University (UNED, Spain). Since the end of 2012, she is a project manager in KRONIKGUNE. Her main research focus is on patient-centered integrated care, patient empowerment and telemedicine.

Kurt Zatloukal, M.D., professor of Pathology at the Medical University of Graz, Austria. He coordinated the preparatory phase of the European biobanking and biomolecular research infrastructure (BBMRI) within the 7th EU framework programme. In this context it was crucial to establish Europe-wide harmonized processes and quality criteria that facilitate transnational research collaboration and are compliant with the requirements of latest -omics technologies as well as with ethical and legal regulations. Furthermore, he leads in the FP7-funded large integrated project SPIDIA the development of new European standards and norms for pre-analytical processing of tissue samples.

Kurt Zatloukal was member of the OECD task force on biological resource centres and the Roadmap Working Group of the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures. Moreover, he contributed to the OECD best practice guidelines for biological resource centres, the regulations for genetic testing of the Austrian Gene Technology Law, and was member of the Bioethics Commission at the Austrian Federal Chancellery. He has published more than 150 scientific papers and was co-inventor of 15 patent applications.

Friedrich Zettinig; (1948), Austrian. Mayor of Bad Hofgastein; education and gastronomy apprenticeship in Bad Hofgastein, certified ski instructor, ÖSV (Austrian Ski Association) trainer, hiking guide and bio trainer; international working experience as trainer and ski instructor (e.g. USA and Australia); spokesman for sports and events of the Spa & Tourist Office Bad Hofgastein. For more than 20 years Zettinig headed the local ski school and was president of the ski club, and in this function he organised and realised numerous regional, national and international ski competitions. Since 2004 he has been a local councillor, in 2008 he became vice-mayor and in March 2009 he was elected Mayor of Bad Hofgastein.

Peteris Zilgalvis
Head of Unit, eHealth and Well Being, DG Connect,
European Commission

Previously, he was Head of the Unit, Infectious Diseases and Public Health in the Health Research Directorate. Until 2010, he was Head of the Governance and Ethics Unit, Directorate Science, Economy and Society at DG Research, European Commission. From 1997 to 2005, he was Deputy Head of the Bioethics Department of the Council of Europe, in its Directorate General of Legal Affairs. In addition, he has held various positions in the Latvian civil service (Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Environment). He was Senior Environmental Law Advisor to the World Bank/Russian Federation Environmental Management Project and was Regional Environmental Specialist for the Baltic Countries at the World Bank. P. Zilgalvis studied political science (cum laude) at the University of California, Los Angeles.

Dr Piroska Östlin is Acting Director and Programme Manager of the Vulnerability and Health Programme at the WHO Regional Office for Europe, Division of Policy and Governance of Health. She is also the Regional Focal Point for WHO Collaborating Centres and Expert  Advisory Panels & Committees. Dr Östlin is Associate Professor in Public Health at the Karolinska Institute in Sweden with a Ph.D in Medical Science from the University of Uppsala. Before joining WHO, she has been working extensively for the Organization as special adviser on social determinants of health and temporary adviser on gender and health equity issues. Dr Östlin was coordinator of two WHO task forces (in 2004 and 2009) on Research Priorities for Equity in Health. She was Member of the WHO Scientific Group on Equity Analysis and Research in 2009. Together with Gita Sen, Östlin was coordinator of the Women and Gender Equity Knowledge Network of the WHO Commission on Social Determinants of Health (CSDH). Between 2001 and 2010 she was Member of Board of the European Institute of Women’s Health. Her former positions include Secretary of the Swedish National Public Health Commission, Expert in International and Global Health at the Swedish National Institute of Public Health and Member of Board of the Nordic School of Public Health. Her publications include Gender Inequalities in Health: A Swedish Perspective, Harvard University Press, 2001 (with Danielsson et al), Engendering International Health; The Challenge of Equity, MIT Press, 2002 (with Sen G and George A), and “Gender Equity in Health: The Shifting Frontiers of Evidence and Action”, Routledge, 2010 (with Sen G.).

 

(last updated 11.09.2015)
